metadata.section_title: Requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom

chunks.text:
### Requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom

1.   298. The requirements to be met by a person seeking indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled in the United Kingdom are that he: 
    1.   (i) is seeking to remain with a parent, parents or a relative in one of the following circumstances: 
        1.   (a) both parents are present and settled in the United Kingdom; or
        2.   (b) one parent is present and settled in the United Kingdom and the other parent is dead; or
        3.   (c) one parent is present and settled in the United Kingdom and has had sole responsibility for the child’s upbringing or the child normally lives with this parent and not their other parent; or
        4.   (d) one parent or a relative is present and settled in the United Kingdom and there are serious and compelling family or other considerations which make exclusion of the child undesirable and suitable arrangements have been made for the child’s care; and

    2.   (ii) has or has had limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, and 
        1.   (a) is under the age of 18; or
        2.   (b) was given leave to enter or remain with a view to settlement under paragraph 302 or Appendix FM; or
        3.   (c) was admitted into the UK in accordance with paragraph 319R and has completed a period of 2 years limited leave as the child of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection who is now present and settled in the UK or as the child of a former refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection who is now a British Citizen, or
        4.   (d) the applicant has limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom in accordance with paragraph 319X, as the child of a relative with limited leave to remain as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection in the United Kingdom and who is now present and settled here; or
        5.   (e) was last given limited leave to remain under paragraph 298A; or
        6.   (f) was last given entry clearance or permission to stay under Appendix Adoption or the adopted children rules in this Part; and

    3.   (iii) is not leading an independent life, is unmarried, and has not formed an independent family unit; and
    4.   (iv) can, and will, be accommodated adequately by the parent, parents or relative the child was admitted to join, without recourse to public funds in accommodation which the parent, parents or relative the child was admitted to join, own or occupy exclusively; and
    5.   (v) can, and will, be maintained adequately by the parent, parents or relative the child was admitted to join, without recourse to public funds; and
    6.   (vi) does not fall for refusal under Part Suitability, and
    7.   (vii) if aged 18 or over, was admitted to the United Kingdom under paragraph 302, or Appendix FM, or 319R or 319X and has demonstrated sufficient knowledge of the English language and sufficient knowledge about life in the United Kingdom in accordance with Appendix KoLL.

1.   298A. If an applicant does not meet the requirements of paragraph 298 only because: 
    1.   (a) the applicant does not meet the requirement in paragraph 298(vi) by reason of a sentence or disposal of a type mentioned in paragraph SUI 5.3. of Part Suitability of these Rules; or
    2.   (b) an applicant aged 18 or over does not meet the requirement in paragraph 298(vii); or
    3.   (c) the applicant would otherwise be refused indefinite leave to remain under paragraph SUI 5.3. of Part Suitability of these Rules, the applicant may be granted limited leave to remain for a period not exceeding 30 months and subject to a condition of no recourse to public funds.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children seeking indefinite leave to remain in the UK as dependents of settled or admitted relatives. They must be under 18, have limited leave, and be with a parent or relative in certain family circumstances, including sole responsibility or compelling family reasons. Key conditions include existing lawful stay and specific family relationships or situations, with exceptions for certain settled or admitted family members.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules part 8: family members
Part: Immigration Rules part 8: family members
Section ID: 1
Section: Requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom
Topic: eligibility

Summary: This provision applies to children seeking indefinite leave to remain in the UK as dependents of settled or admitted relatives. They must be under 18, have limited leave, and be with a parent or relative in certain family circumstances, including sole responsibility or compelling family reasons. Key conditions include existing lawful stay and specific family relationships or situations, with exceptions for certain settled or admitted family members.

### Requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom

1.   298. The requirements to be met by a person seeking indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled in the United Kingdom are that he: 
    1.   (i) is seeking to remain with a parent, parents or a relative in one of the following circumstances: 
        1.   (a) both parents are present and settled in the United Kingdom; or
        2.   (b) one parent is present and settled in the United Kingdom and the other parent is dead; or
        3.   (c) one parent is present and settled in the United Kingdom and has had sole responsibility for the child’s upbringing or the child normally lives with this parent and not their other parent; or
        4.   (d) one parent or a relative is present and settled in the United Kingdom and there are serious and compelling family or other considerations which make exclusion of the child undesirable and suitable arrangements have been made for the child’s care; and

    2.   (ii) has or has had limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, and 
        1.   (a) is under the age of 18; or
        2.   (b) was given leave to enter or remain with a view to settlement under paragraph 302 or Appendix FM; or
        3.   (c) was admitted into the UK in accordance with paragraph 319R and has completed a period of 2 years limited leave as the child of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection who is now present and settled in the UK or as the child of a former refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection who is now a British Citizen, or
        4.   (d) the applicant has limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom in accordance with paragraph 319X, as the child of a relative with limited leave to remain as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection in the United Kingdom and who is now present and settled here; or
        5.   (e) was last given limited leave to remain under paragraph 298A; or
        6.   (f) was last given entry clearance or permission to stay under Appendix Adoption or the adopted children rules in this Part; and

    3.   (iii) is not leading an independent life, is unmarried, and has not formed an independent family unit; and
    4.   (iv) can, and will, be accommodated adequately by the parent, parents or relative the child was admitted to join, without recourse to public funds in accommodation which the parent, parents or relative the child was admitted to join, own or occupy exclusively; and
    5.   (v) can, and will, be maintained adequately by the parent, parents or relative the child was admitted to join, without recourse to public funds; and
    6.   (vi) does not fall for refusal under Part Suitability, and
    7.   (vii) if aged 18 or over, was admitted to the United Kingdom under paragraph 302, or Appendix FM, or 319R or 319X and has demonstrated sufficient knowledge of the English language and sufficient knowledge about life in the United Kingdom in accordance with Appendix KoLL.

1.   298A. If an applicant does not meet the requirements of paragraph 298 only because: 
    1.   (a) the applicant does not meet the requirement in paragraph 298(vi) by reason of a sentence or disposal of a type mentioned in paragraph SUI 5.3. of Part Suitability of these Rules; or
    2.   (b) an applicant aged 18 or over does not meet the requirement in paragraph 298(vii); or
    3.   (c) the applicant would otherwise be refused indefinite leave to remain under paragraph SUI 5.3. of Part Suitability of these Rules, the applicant may be granted limited leave to remain for a period not exceeding 30 months and subject to a condition of no recourse to public funds.

metadata.section_title: Indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom

chunks.text:
### Indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom

1.   299. Indefinite leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom may be granted provided that, on arrival, a valid passport or other identity document is produced to the Immigration Officer and the applicant has entry clearance for entry in this capacity. Indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled in the United Kingdom may be granted provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 298 is met.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children of settled or admitted relatives in the UK seeking indefinite leave to enter or remain. They must produce a valid passport and have entry clearance, with indefinite leave granted if the Secretary of State is satisfied that all specified conditions are met.

### Indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom

1.   299. Indefinite leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom may be granted provided that, on arrival, a valid passport or other identity document is produced to the Immigration Officer and the applicant has entry clearance for entry in this capacity. Indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled in the United Kingdom may be granted provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 298 is met.

metadata.section_title: Refusal of indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom

chunks.text:
### Refusal of indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom

1.   300. Indefinite leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled or being admitted for settlement in the United Kingdom is to be refused if on arrival, a valid passport or other identity document is not produced to the Immigration Officer and the applicant does not have entry clearance for entry in this capacity. Indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent, parents or a relative present and settled in the United Kingdom is to be refused if the Secretary of State is not satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 298 is met.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children seeking indefinite leave to enter or remain as relatives of settled or settled-status UK residents. It requires production of valid identity documents upon arrival and satisfaction of specific eligibility criteria; failure to meet these conditions results in refusal.

metadata.section_title: Requirements for limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement as the child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement

chunks.text:
### Requirements for limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement as the child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement

1.   301. The requirements to be met by a person seeking limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement as the child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement are that he: 
    1.   (i) is seeking leave to enter to accompany or join or remain with a parent or parents in one of the following circumstances: 
        1.   (a) one parent is present and settled in the United Kingdom or being admitted on the same occasion for settlement and the other parent is being or has been given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement; or
        2.   (b) one parent is being or has been given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement and has had sole responsibility for the child’s upbringing; or
        3.   (c) one parent is being or has been given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement and there are serious and compelling family or other considerations which make exclusion of the child undesirable and suitable arrangements have been made for the child’s care; and

    2.   (ii) is under the age of 18; and
    3.   (iii) is not leading an independent life, is unmarried and is not a civil partner, and has not formed an independent family unit; and
    4.   (iv) can, and will, be accommodated adequately without recourse to public funds, in accommodation which the parent or parents own or occupy exclusively; and
    5.   (iva) can, and will, be maintained adequately by the parent or parents without recourse to public funds; and
    6.   (ivb) does not qualify for limited leave to enter as a child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection under paragraph 319R; and
    7.   (v) (where an application is made for limited leave to remain with a view to settlement) has limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom; and
    8.   (vi) if seeking leave to enter, holds a valid United Kingdom entry clearance for entry in this capacity.
chunks.summary: The provision applies to children under 18 seeking limited leave to enter or remain in the UK with a parent granted limited leave with a view to settlement. The child must be accompanying or joining a parent meeting specific circumstances (e.g., parent settled or with settled leave, or sole responsibility), and must not be leading an independent life. Conditions include age, relationship, and family considerations.

metadata.section_title: Limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement as the child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement

chunks.text:
### Limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement as the child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement

1.   302. A person seeking limited leave to enter the United Kingdom with a view to settlement as the child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement may be admitted for a period not exceeding 27 months provided he is able, on arrival, to produce to the Immigration Officer a valid passport or other identity document and the applicant has entry clearance for entry in this capacity. A person seeking limited leave to remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement as the child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom with a view to settlement may be given limited leave to remain for a period not exceeding 27 months provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 301 (i)-(v) is met.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children seeking limited leave to enter or remain in the UK for settlement as a parent’s child. They must obtain entry clearance, produce valid identification, and are generally granted up to 27 months leave if all requirements are met; exceptions apply based on specific criteria under paragraph 301.

metadata.section_title: Requirements for limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner

chunks.text:
### Requirements for limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner

1.   303A. The requirements to be met by a person seeking limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner, are that: 
    1.   (i) he is seeking to accompany or join a parent who is, on the same occasion that the child seeks admission, being admitted as a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner , or who has been admitted as a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner; and
    2.   (ii) he is under the age of 18; and
    3.   (iii) he is not leading an independent life, is unmarried and is not a civil partner, and has not formed an independent family unit; and
    4.   (iv) he can and will be maintained and accommodated adequately without recourse to public funds with the parent admitted or being admitted as a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner; and
    5.   (v) there are serious and compelling family or other considerations which make the child’s exclusion undesirable, that suitable arrangements have been made for his care in the United Kingdom, and there is no other person outside the United Kingdom who could reasonably be expected to care for him; and
    6.   (vi) he holds a valid United Kingdom entry clearance for entry in this capacity.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children seeking limited leave to enter the UK as the child of a fiancé(e) or proposed civil partner. The child must be under 18, unmarried, not leading an independent life, and adequately maintained without public funds; there must also be compelling family reasons for entry, and the child must hold valid UK entry clearance.

metadata.section_title: Limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a parent who is being, or has been admitted to the United Kingdom as a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner

chunks.text:
### Limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a parent who is being, or has been admitted to the United Kingdom as a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner

1.   303B. A person seeking limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner, may be granted limited leave to enter the United Kingdom for a period not in excess of that granted to the fiance(e) or proposed civil partner, provided that on arrival a valid passport or other identity document is produced to the Immigration Officer and the applicant has entry clearance for entry in this capacity. Where the period of limited leave granted to a fiance(e) will expire in more than 6 months, a person seeking limited leave to enter as the child of the fiance(e) or proposed civil partner should be granted leave for a period not exceeding six months.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children seeking limited leave to enter the UK as the child of a fiancé(e) or proposed civil partner. They must produce valid identification and have entry clearance, with their leave limited to that of their parent, typically up to six months if the parent's leave exceeds six months.

chunks.text:
### Requirements for an extension of stay in the United Kingdom as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner

1.   303D. The requirements to be met by a person seeking an extension of stay in the United Kingdom as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner are that: 
    1.   (i) the applicant was admitted with a valid United Kingdom entry clearance as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner; and
    2.   (ii) the applicant is the child of a parent who has been granted limited leave to enter, or an extension of stay, as a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner; and
    3.   (iii) the requirements of paragraph 303A (ii) - (v) are met.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children seeking an extension of stay as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner. They must have been admitted with valid entry clearance, have a parent with valid leave or extension as a fiancé(e) or civil partner, and meet additional specific requirements. Exceptions or thresholds are not specified in this excerpt.

### Requirements for an extension of stay in the United Kingdom as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner

1.   303D. The requirements to be met by a person seeking an extension of stay in the United Kingdom as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner are that: 
    1.   (i) the applicant was admitted with a valid United Kingdom entry clearance as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner; and
    2.   (ii) the applicant is the child of a parent who has been granted limited leave to enter, or an extension of stay, as a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner; and
    3.   (iii) the requirements of paragraph 303A (ii) - (v) are met.

chunks.text:
### Extension of stay in the United Kingdom as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner

1.   303E. An extension of stay as the child of a fiance(e) or proposed civil partner may be granted provided that the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 303D is met.

metadata.section_title: Children born in the United Kingdom who are not British citizens

chunks.text:
### Children born in the United Kingdom who are not British citizens

1.   304. This paragraph and paragraphs 305-309 apply only to dependent children under 18 years of age who are unmarried and are not civil partners and who were born in the United Kingdom on or after 1 January 1983 (when the British Nationality Act 1981 came into force) but who, because neither of their parents was a British Citizen or settled in the United Kingdom at the time of their birth, are not British Citizens and are therefore subject to immigration control. Such a child requires leave to enter where admission to the United Kingdom is sought, and leave to remain where permission is sought for the child to be allowed to stay in the United Kingdom. If he qualifies for entry clearance, leave to enter or leave to remain under any other part of these Rules, a child who was born in the United Kingdom but is not a British Citizen may be granted entry clearance, leave to enter or leave to remain in accordance with the provisions of that other part.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to non-British children under 18 born in the UK after 1983 who are dependent, unmarried, and not settled. They require leave to enter or remain unless qualifying under other immigration rules; exceptions depend on their eligibility for different statuses.

### Children born in the United Kingdom who are not British citizens

1.   304. This paragraph and paragraphs 305-309 apply only to dependent children under 18 years of age who are unmarried and are not civil partners and who were born in the United Kingdom on or after 1 January 1983 (when the British Nationality Act 1981 came into force) but who, because neither of their parents was a British Citizen or settled in the United Kingdom at the time of their birth, are not British Citizens and are therefore subject to immigration control. Such a child requires leave to enter where admission to the United Kingdom is sought, and leave to remain where permission is sought for the child to be allowed to stay in the United Kingdom. If he qualifies for entry clearance, leave to enter or leave to remain under any other part of these Rules, a child who was born in the United Kingdom but is not a British Citizen may be granted entry clearance, leave to enter or leave to remain in accordance with the provisions of that other part.

metadata.section_title: Requirements for leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent or parents given leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom

chunks.text:
### Requirements for leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent or parents given leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom

1.   305. The requirements to be met by a child born in the United Kingdom who is not a British Citizen who seeks leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent or parents given leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom are that he: 
    1.   (i) (a) is accompanying or seeking to join or remain with a parent or parents who have, or are given, leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom; or 
        1.   (b) is accompanying or seeking to join or remain with a parent or parents one of whom is a British Citizen or has the right of abode in the United Kingdom; or
        2.   (c) is a child in respect of whom the parental rights and duties are vested solely in a local authority; and

    2.   (ii) is under the age of 18; and
    3.   (iii) was born in the United Kingdom; and
    4.   (iv) is not leading an independent life, is unmarried and is not a civil partner, and has not formed an independent family unit; and
    5.   (v) (where an application is made for leave to enter) has not been away from the United Kingdom for more than 2 years.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children born in the UK, seeking leave to enter or remain as the child of a parent with UK leave or British citizenship. The child must be under 18, born in the UK, not leading an independent life, unmarried, and have not been outside the UK for over 2 years (if applying for entry). These conditions ensure eligibility based on familial ties and age.

### Requirements for leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent or parents given leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom

1.   305. The requirements to be met by a child born in the United Kingdom who is not a British Citizen who seeks leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the child of a parent or parents given leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom are that he: 
    1.   (i) (a) is accompanying or seeking to join or remain with a parent or parents who have, or are given, leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom; or 
        1.   (b) is accompanying or seeking to join or remain with a parent or parents one of whom is a British Citizen or has the right of abode in the United Kingdom; or
        2.   (c) is a child in respect of whom the parental rights and duties are vested solely in a local authority; and

    2.   (ii) is under the age of 18; and
    3.   (iii) was born in the United Kingdom; and
    4.   (iv) is not leading an independent life, is unmarried and is not a civil partner, and has not formed an independent family unit; and
    5.   (v) (where an application is made for leave to enter) has not been away from the United Kingdom for more than 2 years.

metadata.section_title: Leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom

chunks.text:
### Leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom

1.   306. A child born in the United Kingdom who is not a British Citizen and who requires leave to enter or remain in the circumstances set out in paragraph 304 may be given leave to enter for the same period as his parent or parents where paragraph 305 (i)(a) applies, provided the Immigration Officer is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 305 (ii)-(v) is met. Where leave to remain is sought, the child may be granted leave to remain for the same period as his parent or parents where paragraph 305 (i)(a) applies, provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 305 (ii)-(iv) is met. Where the parent or parents have or are given periods of leave of different duration, the child may be given leave to whichever period is longer except that if the parents are living apart the child should be given leave for the same period as the parent who has day to day responsibility for him.
2.   307. If a child does not qualify for leave to enter or remain because neither of his parents has a current leave, (and neither of them is a British Citizen or has the right of abode), he will normally be refused leave to enter or remain, even if each of the requirements of paragraph 305 (ii)-(v) has been satisfied. However, he may be granted leave to enter or remain for a period not exceeding 3 months if both of his parents are in the United Kingdom and it appears unlikely that they will be removed in the immediate future, and there is no other person outside the United Kingdom who could reasonably be expected to care for him.
3.   308. A child born in the United Kingdom who is not a British Citizen and who requires leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom in the circumstances set out in paragraph 304 may be given indefinite leave to enter where paragraph 305 (i)(b) or (i)(c) applies provided the Immigration Officer is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 305 (ii)-(v) is met. Where an application is for leave to remain, such a child may be granted indefinite leave to remain where paragraph 305 (i)(b) or (i)(c) applies, provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 305 (ii)-(iv) is met.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children in the UK seeking leave to enter or remain. It allows children not British Citizens to be granted leave matching their parent(s)’ duration, subject to meeting specific requirements; if parents lack valid leave, the child will generally be refused unless both are in the UK and a short 3-month leave is appropriate.

However, he may be granted leave to enter or remain for a period not exceeding 3 months if both of his parents are in the United Kingdom and it appears unlikely that they will be removed in the immediate future, and there is no other person outside the United Kingdom who could reasonably be expected to care for him.
3.   308. A child born in the United Kingdom who is not a British Citizen and who requires leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom in the circumstances set out in paragraph 304 may be given indefinite leave to enter where paragraph 305 (i)(b) or (i)(c) applies provided the Immigration Officer is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 305 (ii)-(v) is met. Where an application is for leave to remain, such a child may be granted indefinite leave to remain where paragraph 305 (i)(b) or (i)(c) applies, provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 305 (ii)-(iv) is met.

### Refusal of leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom

1.   309. Leave to enter the United Kingdom where the circumstances set out in paragraph 304 apply is to be refused if the Immigration Officer is not satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 305 is met. Leave to remain for such a child is to be refused if the Secretary of State is not satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 305 (i)-(iv) is met.

### Parents, grandparents and other dependent relatives of persons present and settled in the United Kingdom

metadata.section_title: Requirements for indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person present and settled in the United Kingdom

chunks.text:
### Requirements for indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person present and settled in the United Kingdom

1.   317. The requirements to be met by a person seeking indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person present and settled in the United Kingdom are that the person:
2.   (i) is related to a person present and settled in the United Kingdom in one of the following ways: 
    1.   (a) parent or grandparent who is divorced, widowed, single or separated aged 65 years or over; or
    2.   (b) parents or grandparents travelling together of whom at least one is aged 65 or over; or
    3.   (c) a parent or grandparent aged 65 or over who has entered into a second relationship of marriage or civil partnership but cannot look to the spouse, civil partner or children of that second relationship for financial support; and where the person settled in the United Kingdom is able and willing to maintain the parent or grandparent and any spouse or civil partner or child of the second relationship who would be admissible as a dependant; or
    4.   (d) parent or grandparent under the age of 65 if living alone outside the United Kingdom in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; or
    5.   (e) parents or grandparents travelling together who are both under the age of 65 if living in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; or
    6.   (f) the son, daughter, sister, brother, uncle or aunt over the age of 18 if living alone outside the United Kingdom in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; and

3.   (ii) is joining or accompanying a person who is present and settled in the United Kingdom or who is on the same occasion being admitted for settlement; and
4.   (iii) is financially wholly or mainly dependent on the relative present and settled in the United Kingdom; and
5.   (iv) can, and will, be accommodated adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds, in accommodation which the sponsor owns or occupies exclusively; and
6.   (iva) can, and will, be maintained adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds; and
7.   (v) has no other close relatives in his own country to whom he could turn for financial support; and
8.   (vi) if seeking leave to enter, holds a valid United Kingdom entry clearance for entry in this capacity; and
9.   (vii) does not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking indefinite leave as a parent, grandparent, or dependent relative must prove specific family relationships and meet criteria related to age, relationship status, and exceptional circumstances. Key conditions include being over 65 and unable to seek support from other family members, or under 65 only in exceptional compassionate cases.

### Requirements for indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person present and settled in the United Kingdom

    4.   (d) parent or grandparent under the age of 65 if living alone outside the United Kingdom in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; or
    5.   (e) parents or grandparents travelling together who are both under the age of 65 if living in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; or
    6.   (f) the son, daughter, sister, brother, uncle or aunt over the age of 18 if living alone outside the United Kingdom in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; and

3.   (ii) is joining or accompanying a person who is present and settled in the United Kingdom or who is on the same occasion being admitted for settlement; and
4.   (iii) is financially wholly or mainly dependent on the relative present and settled in the United Kingdom; and
5.   (iv) can, and will, be accommodated adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds, in accommodation which the sponsor owns or occupies exclusively; and
6.   (iva) can, and will, be maintained adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds; and
7.   (v) has no other close relatives in his own country to whom he could turn for financial support; and
8.   (vi) if seeking leave to enter, holds a valid United Kingdom entry clearance for entry in this capacity; and
9.   (vii) does not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

metadata.section_title: Indefinite leave to enter or remain as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person present and settled in the United Kingdom

chunks.text:
### Indefinite leave to enter or remain as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person present and settled in the United Kingdom

1.   Indefinite leave to enter the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person present and settled in the United Kingdom may be granted provided, on arrival, a valid passport or other identity document is produced to the Immigration Officer and the applicant has entry clearance for entry in this capacity. Indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person present and settled in the United Kingdom may be granted provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 317 (i)-(v) is met.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to parents, grandparents, or dependent relatives of persons settled in the UK. They can obtain indefinite leave to enter or remain if they produce valid identity documents, have entry clearance, and meet specific requirements (paragraph 317). Exceptions or thresholds are outlined in the detailed conditions of paragraph 317.

metadata.section_title: 319A. Purpose

chunks.text:
### 319A. Purpose

This route is for the spouse, civil partner, unmarried or same-sex partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker (Partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker). Paragraphs 277 to 280 of these Rules apply to spouses or civil partners of Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker; paragraph 277 of these Rules applies to civil partners of Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker; and paragraph 295AA of these Rules applies to unmarried and same-sex partners of Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to spouses, civil partners, and unmarried or same-sex partners of Relevant Points Based System or Appendix W Workers. It sets out the process for applying under this route, with specific rules (paragraphs 277, 280, and 295AA) covering different partner types. Critical conditions include being in a genuine partnership with the worker and meeting applicable eligibility criteria.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules part 8: family members
Part: Immigration Rules part 8: family members
Section ID: 319A
Section: 319A. Purpose
Topic: family

Summary: This provision applies to spouses, civil partners, and unmarried or same-sex partners of Relevant Points Based System or Appendix W Workers. It sets out the process for applying under this route, with specific rules (paragraphs 277, 280, and 295AA) covering different partner types. Critical conditions include being in a genuine partnership with the worker and meeting applicable eligibility criteria.

### 319A. Purpose

This route is for the spouse, civil partner, unmarried or same-sex partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker (Partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker). Paragraphs 277 to 280 of these Rules apply to spouses or civil partners of Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker; paragraph 277 of these Rules applies to civil partners of Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker; and paragraph 295AA of these Rules applies to unmarried and same-sex partners of Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker.

metadata.section_title: 319B. Entry to the UK

chunks.text:
### 319B. Entry to the UK

1.   (a) any person wishing to enter as the Partner of a relevant Points Based System Migrant Worker must on arrival in the UK have a valid entry clearance for entry under this route.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners entering the UK as dependents of Points-Based System Migrant Workers. They must have valid entry clearance before arrival. No exceptions are specified.

metadata.section_title: 319C. Requirements for entry clearance or leave to remain

chunks.text:
### 319C. Requirements for entry clearance or leave to remain

To qualify for entry clearance or leave to remain as the Partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, an applicant must meet the requirements listed below. If the applicant meets these requirements, entry clearance or leave to remain will be granted. If the applicant does not meet these requirements, the application will be refused.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking entry clearance or leave to remain as Partners of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must meet specific eligibility criteria; failure to do so will result in refusal.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules part 8: family members
Part: Immigration Rules part 8: family members
Section ID: 319C
Section: 319C. Requirements for entry clearance or leave to remain
Topic: leave-to-enter

Summary: Applicants seeking entry clearance or leave to remain as Partners of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must meet specific eligibility criteria; failure to do so will result in refusal.

### 319C. Requirements for entry clearance or leave to remain

To qualify for entry clearance or leave to remain as the Partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, an applicant must meet the requirements listed below. If the applicant meets these requirements, entry clearance or leave to remain will be granted. If the applicant does not meet these requirements, the application will be refused.

metadata.section_title: **Requirements:**

chunks.text:
### **Requirements:**

1.   (a) The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability, and if applying for leave to remain, must not be an illegal entrant.
2.   (b) The applicant must be the spouse or civil partner, unmarried or same-sex partner of a person who: 
    1.   (i) has valid leave to enter or remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or
    2.   (ii) is, at the same time, being granted entry clearance or leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or
    3.   (iii) has indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or is at the same time being granted indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, where the applicant is applying for further leave to remain, or has been refused indefinite leave to remain solely because the applicant has not met the requirements of paragraph 319E(g), and was last granted leave:
    4.   (1) as the partner of that same Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker: or
    5.   (2) as the spouse or civil partner, unmarried or same-sex partner of that person at a time when that person had leave under another category of these Rules; or
    6.   (iv) has become a British Citizen where prior to that they held indefinite leave to Remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker and where the applicant is applying for further leave to remain, or has been refused indefinite leave to remain solely because the application has not met the requirements of paragraph 319E(g), and was last granted leave:
    7.   (1) as the partner of that same Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or
    8.   (2) as the spouse or civil partner, unmarried or same-sex partner of that person at a time when that person had leave under another category of these Rules.

3.   (c) An applicant who is the unmarried or same-sex partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must also meet the following requirements: 
    1.   (i) any previous marriage or civil partnership or similar relationship by the applicant or the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker with another person must have permanently broken down,
    2.   (ii) the applicant and the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must not be so closely related that they would be prohibited from marrying each other in the UK, and
    3.   (iii) the applicant and the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must have been living together in a relationship similar to marriage or civil partnership for a period of at least 2 years.

4.   (d) The marriage or civil partnership, or relationship similar to marriage or civil partnership, must be genuine and subsisting at the time the application is made.
5.   (e) The applicant and the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must intend to live with the other as their spouse or civil partner, unmarried or same-sex partner throughout the applicants stay in the UK.
6.   (f) The applicant must not intend to stay in the UK beyond any period of leave granted to the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker.
7.   (g) Unless the applicant is applying as the Partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant who is a Tier 1 (Investor) Migrant, there must be a sufficient level of funds available to the applicant, as set out in Appendix E.
8.   (h) An applicant who is applying for leave to remain must not have last been granted: 
    1.   (i) entry clearance or leave as a: 
        1.   (a) visitor, including where they entered the United Kingdom from the Republic of Ireland to stay under the terms of articles 3A and 4 of the Immigration (Control of Entry through the Republic of Ireland) Order 1972 (as amended by the Immigration (Control of Entry through Republic of Ireland) (Amendment) Order 2014) on the basis of a visa issued by the Republic of Ireland authorities endorsed with the letters “BIVS” for the purpose of travelling and staying in the Republic for a period of 90 days or fewer; or
        2.   (b) short-term student or short term student (child); or
        3.   unless the applicant is applying as the Partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant who has, or is being granted, leave to remain as a Tier 5 (Temporary Worker) Migrant in the creative and sporting subcategory on the basis of having met the requirement at paragraph 245ZQ(b)(ii);

    2.   (ii) temporary admission;
    3.   (iii) temporary release; or
    4.   (iv) after the date on which paragraph 1 of Schedule 10 to the Immigration Act 2016 is commenced, a grant of immigration bail in circumstances in which temporary admission or temporary release would previously have been granted.

9.   (i) DELETED
10.   (j) The applicant must not be in the UK in breach of immigration laws except that, where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, any current period of overstaying will be disregarded.
11.   (k) Where the applicant is 18 years of age or older and seeking entry clearance as the partner of a person specified below, the applicant must provide a criminal record certificate from the relevant authority in any country in which they have been present for 12 months (whether continuously or in total) or more in the past 10 years, while aged 18 or over. This requirement does not need to be met where the Secretary of State is satisfied, by way of an explanation provided in or with the application, that it is not reasonably practicable for the applicant to obtain a certificate from the relevant authority. 
    1.   (1) For the purposes of sub-paragraph (k), a specified person is a person who is seeking, or has been granted, entry clearance or leave to remain as a: 
        1.   (a) Tier 1 (Entrepreneur) Migrant,
        2.   (b) Tier 1 (Investor) Migrant,
        3.   (c) DELETED

12.   (m) If the applicant has failed to provide a criminal record certificate or an explanation in accordance with sub-paragraph (k), the decision maker may contact the applicant or his representative in writing, and request the certificate(s) or explanation. The requested certificate(s) or explanation must be received at the address specified in the request within 28 calendar days of the date of the request.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners of Relevant Points Based System or Appendix W Workers. Applicants must not be illegal entrants or failed suitability tests and must be spouses, civil partners, or unmarried/same-sex partners of eligible migrants. Critical conditions include having valid leave or indefinite residence and meeting specific relationship and immigration status requirements.

        2.   (b) short-term student or short term student (child); or
        3.   unless the applicant is applying as the Partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant who has, or is being granted, leave to remain as a Tier 5 (Temporary Worker) Migrant in the creative and sporting subcategory on the basis of having met the requirement at paragraph 245ZQ(b)(ii);

    2.   (ii) temporary admission;
    3.   (iii) temporary release; or
    4.   (iv) after the date on which paragraph 1 of Schedule 10 to the Immigration Act 2016 is commenced, a grant of immigration bail in circumstances in which temporary admission or temporary release would previously have been granted.

9.   (i) DELETED
10.   (j) The applicant must not be in the UK in breach of immigration laws except that, where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, any current period of overstaying will be disregarded.
11.   (k) Where the applicant is 18 years of age or older and seeking entry clearance as the partner of a person specified below, the applicant must provide a criminal record certificate from the relevant authority in any country in which they have been present for 12 months (whether continuously or in total) or more in the past 10 years, while aged 18 or over.         2.   (b) Tier 1 (Investor) Migrant,
        3.   (c) DELETED

12. The requested certificate(s) or explanation must be received at the address specified in the request within 28 calendar days of the date of the request.

metadata.section_title: 319D. Period and conditions of grant

chunks.text:
### 319D. Period and conditions of grant

1.   (a) (i) Entry clearance or limited leave to remain will be granted for a period which expires on the same day as the leave granted to the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or
2.   (ii) If the Relevant Points-Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker has indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or is, at the same time being granted indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or where the Relevant Points-Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker has since become a British Citizen, leave to remain will be granted to the applicant for a period of 3 years.
3.   (b) Entry clearance and leave to remain under this route will be subject to the following conditions: 
    1.   (i) no recourse to public funds,
    2.   (ii) DELETED
    3.   (iii) DELETED
    4.   (iv) DELETED
    5.   (v) no employment as a professional sportsperson (including as a sports coach),
    6.   (vi) study subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS where the applicant is 18 years of age or over at the time their leave is granted, or will be aged 18 before their period of limited leave expires.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to family members applying for entry clearance or limited leave linked to a Relevant Points-Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker. They must be granted leave coinciding with the migrant's status, typically for 3 years if the migrant has indefinite leave or is a British citizen, and adhere to conditions such as no public funds, no professional sports employment, and, if aged 18+, ATAS requirements.

metadata.section_title: 319E. Requirements for indefinite leave to remain

chunks.text:
### 319E. Requirements for indefinite leave to remain

To qualify for indefinite leave to remain as the Partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, an applicant must meet the requirements listed below. If the applicant meets these requirements, indefinite leave to remain will be granted. If the applicant does not meet these requirements, the application will be refused.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners of Relevant Points Based System or Appendix W workers seeking indefinite leave to remain. Applicants must demonstrate they meet specified requirements to qualify; failure to do so will result in refusal.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules part 8: family members

Section ID: 319E
Section: 319E. Requirements for indefinite leave to remain
Topic: leave-to-remain

Summary: This provision applies to partners of Relevant Points Based System or Appendix W workers seeking indefinite leave to remain. Applicants must demonstrate they meet specified requirements to qualify; failure to do so will result in refusal.

### 319E. Requirements for indefinite leave to remain

To qualify for indefinite leave to remain as the Partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, an applicant must meet the requirements listed below. If the applicant meets these requirements, indefinite leave to remain will be granted. If the applicant does not meet these requirements, the application will be refused.

metadata.section_title: Requirements:

chunks.text:
### Requirements:

1.   (a) The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability and must not be an illegal entrant.
2.   (b) The applicant must be the spouse or civil partner, unmarried or same-sex partner of a person who: 
    1.   (i) has indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker; or
    2.   (ii) is, at the same time being granted indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or
    3.   (iii) has become a British Citizen where prior to that they held indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker.

3.   (c) The applicant must have, or have last been granted, leave as the partner of the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker who: 
    1.   (i) has indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker; or
    2.   (ii) is, at the same time being granted indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or
    3.   (iii) has become a British Citizen where prior to that they held indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker.

4.   (d) The applicant and the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must have been living together in the UK in a marriage or civil partnership, or in a relationship similar to marriage or civil partnership, for at least a continuous period of 5 years, during which the applicant must: 
    1.   (a) have been in a relationship with the same Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker for this entire period,
    2.   (b) have spent the most recent part of the 5 year period with leave as the Partner of that Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, and during that part of the period have met all of the requirements of paragraph 319C(a) to (e),
    3.   (c) have spent the remainder of the 5 year period, where applicable, with leave as the spouse or civil partner, unmarried or same-sex partner of that person at a time when that person had leave under another category of these Rules, and
    4.   (d) not have been absent from the UK for more than 180 days during any 12 month period in the continuous period, except that: 
        1.   (1) any absence from the UK for the purpose of assisting with a national or international humanitarian or environmental crisis overseas shall not count towards the 180 days, if the applicant provides evidence that this was the purpose of the absence(s), and
        2.   (2) any absence from the UK during periods of leave granted under the Rules in place before 11 January 2018 shall not count towards the 180 days; and
        3.   (3) for any applicant who has or has had leave as the dependant partner of a Tier 2 (General) migrant, where the Tier 2 migrant’s Certificate of Sponsorship Checking Service entry shows that they were sponsored to work in any PhD level occupation listed in paragraph 245AAA(za) of these rules when the absence occurred, any absence of the applicant from the UK to accompany their partner while the partner carried out research activities overseas shall not count towards the 180 days, if the applicant provides evidence from their partner’s sponsor showing that: 
            1.   (a) research was the purpose of the partner’s absence(s); and
            2.   (b) the partner’s sponsor agreed to the partner’s absence(s) for that purpose; and
            3.   (c) the absence(s) were directly related to the Tier 2 employment in the UK.

        4.   (4) for any applicant who has leave as a PBS partner of a settled migrant who, at the point they applied for settlement, held leave as a Tier 2 (General) migrant, where the Certificate of Sponsorship Checking Service entry showed that they were sponsored to work in any PhD level occupation listed in paragraph 245AAA(za) of these rules, any absence from the UK to accompany the settled migrant for the purpose of their research activities overseas shall not count towards the 180 days, if the applicant provides evidence from their settled partner’s employer showing that: 
            1.   (a) the settled partner remained working in a PhD level occupation listed in paragraph 245AAA(za) of these rules during the period of absence(s);
            2.   (b) research was the purpose of the partner’s absence(s); and
            3.   (c) the settled partner’s employer agreed to the absence(s) for that purpose; and
            4.   (d) the absence(s) directly related to the settled partner’s employment in the UK.

    5.   (5) for any applicant who has or has had leave as the Partner of a Tier 1 (Exceptional Talent) Migrant, or Partner of a Global Talent migrant, where the Tier 1 or Global Talent migrant was endorsed by The Royal Society, The British Academy, The Royal Academy of Engineering, or UK Research and Innovation, any absence from the UK for the purpose of research activities overseas shall not count towards the 180 days if it occurred while the applicant held this leave.
    6.   (6) for any applicant who has leave as the Points Based System Partner or Appendix W Partner of a settled migrant who, at the point they applied for settlement, held leave as a Tier 1 (Exceptional Talent) Migrant or Global Talent migrant, where they were endorsed by The Royal Society, The British Academy, The Royal Academy of Engineering, UK Research and Innovation, any absence from the UK for the purpose of research activities overseas shall not count towards the 180 days.
    7.   Any time spent lawfully in the Bailiwick of Guernsey, Bailiwick of Jersey or the Isle of Man shall be deemed to be time spent in the UK.

5.   (e) The marriage or civil partnership, or relationship similar to marriage or civil partnership, must be genuine and subsisting at the time the application is made.
6.   (f) The applicant and the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must intend to live permanently with the other as their spouse or civil partner, unmarried or same-sex partner.
7.   (g) The applicant has demonstrated sufficient knowledge of the English language and sufficient knowledge about life in the United Kingdom, in accordance with Appendix KoLL.
8.   (h) DELETED
9.   (i) The applicant must not be in the UK in breach of immigration laws except that, where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, any current period of overstaying will be disregarded.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners of Relevant Points Based System migrants or Appendix W workers seeking indefinite leave to remain. Applicants must not be illegal entrants, have lived with the sponsor in the UK for at least 5 years, and meet relationship and suitability requirements. Exceptions are limited to partners with continuous UK cohabitation and proper immigration status.

            3.   (c) the absence(s) were directly related to the Tier 2 employment in the UK.

        4.   (4) for any applicant who has leave as a PBS partner of a settled migrant who, at the point they applied for settlement, held leave as a Tier 2 (General) migrant, where the Certificate of Sponsorship Checking Service entry showed that they were sponsored to work in any PhD level occupation listed in paragraph 245AAA(za) of these rules, any absence from the UK to accompany the settled migrant for the purpose of their research activities overseas shall not count towards the 180 days, if the applicant provides evidence from their settled partner’s employer showing that: 
            1.   (a) the settled partner remained working in a PhD level occupation listed in paragraph 245AAA(za) of these rules during the period of absence(s);
            2.   (b) research was the purpose of the partner’s absence(s); and
            3.   (c) the settled partner’s employer agreed to the absence(s) for that purpose; and
            4.   (d) the absence(s) directly related to the settled partner’s employment in the UK.

    5.   (5) for any applicant who has or has had leave as the Partner of a Tier 1 (Exceptional Talent) Migrant, or Partner of a Global Talent migrant, where the Tier 1 or Global Talent migrant was endorsed by The Royal Society, The British Academy, The Royal Academy of Engineering, or UK Research and Innovation, any absence from the UK for the purpose of research activities overseas shall not count towards the 180 days if it occurred while the applicant held this leave.
    6.   (6) for any applicant who has leave as the Points Based System Partner or Appendix W Partner of a settled migrant who, at the point they applied for settlement, held leave as a Tier 1 (Exceptional Talent) Migrant or Global Talent migrant, where they were endorsed by The Royal Society, The British Academy, The Royal Academy of Engineering, UK Research and Innovation, any absence from the UK for the purpose of research activities overseas shall not count towards the 180 days.
    7.   Any time spent lawfully in the Bailiwick of Guernsey, Bailiwick of Jersey or the Isle of Man shall be deemed to be time spent in the UK.

5.   (e) The marriage or civil partnership, or relationship similar to marriage or civil partnership, must be genuine and subsisting at the time the application is made.
6.   (f) The applicant and the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must intend to live permanently with the other as their spouse or civil partner, unmarried or same-sex partner.
7.   (g) The applicant has demonstrated sufficient knowledge of the English language and sufficient knowledge about life in the United Kingdom, in accordance with Appendix KoLL.
8.   (h) DELETED
9.   (i) The applicant must not be in the UK in breach of immigration laws except that, where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, any current period of overstaying will be disregarded.

metadata.section_title: Children of relevant points-based system migrants or Appendix W Worker

chunks.text: ### Children of relevant points-based system migrants or Appendix W Worker
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children of points-based system migrants or Appendix W workers. It requires these children to meet specific visa conditions to stay or join their parents, with eligibility criteria and exceptions depending on their circumstances.

### Children of relevant points-based system migrants or Appendix W Worker

metadata.section_title: 319F. Purpose

chunks.text:
### 319F. Purpose

This route is for the children of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker who are under the age of 18 when they apply to enter under this route. Paragraph 296 of these Rules applies to children of a Relevant Points Based System Migrants or Appendix W Workers.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children under 18 of Relevant Points Based System Migrants or Appendix W Workers. It allows them to apply for entry under this route, subject to the requirements in paragraph 296. Children must be under 18 at application time, with specific rules applying to their eligibility.

It allows them to apply for entry under this route, subject to the requirements in paragraph 296. Children must be under 18 at application time, with specific rules applying to their eligibility.

### 319F. Purpose

This route is for the children of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker who are under the age of 18 when they apply to enter under this route. Paragraph 296 of these Rules applies to children of a Relevant Points Based System Migrants or Appendix W Workers.

metadata.section_title: 319G. Entry to the UK

chunks.text:
### 319G. Entry to the UK

1.   (a) Subject to paragraph (b), all migrants wishing to enter as the Child of a relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must have a valid entry clearance for entry under this route. If they do not have a valid entry clearance, entry will be refused.
2.   (b) DELETED
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children of Points Based System migrants or Appendix W workers seeking UK entry. They must obtain valid entry clearance to enter, with entry refused without it; specific conditions or exceptions are not detailed here.

1.   (a) Subject to paragraph (b), all migrants wishing to enter as the Child of a relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker must have a valid entry clearance for entry under this route. If they do not have a valid entry clearance, entry will be refused.
2.   (b) DELETED

metadata.section_title: 319H. Requirements for entry clearance or leave to remain

chunks.text:
### 319H. Requirements for entry clearance or leave to remain

To qualify for entry clearance or leave to remain under this route, an applicant must meet the requirements listed below. If the applicant meets these requirements, entry clearance or leave to remain will be granted. If the applicant does not meet these requirements, the application will be refused.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to family members seeking entry clearance or leave to remain. Applicants must meet specific requirements outlined in the rules; failure to do so results in refusal. Key conditions include demonstrating eligibility under the route, with no specified exceptions.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules part 8: family members
Part: Immigration Rules part 8: family members
Section ID: 319H
Section: 319H. Requirements for entry clearance or leave to remain
Topic: leave-to-enter

Summary: This provision applies to family members seeking entry clearance or leave to remain. Applicants must meet specific requirements outlined in the rules; failure to do so results in refusal. Key conditions include demonstrating eligibility under the route, with no specified exceptions.

### 319H. Requirements for entry clearance or leave to remain

To qualify for entry clearance or leave to remain under this route, an applicant must meet the requirements listed below. If the applicant meets these requirements, entry clearance or leave to remain will be granted. If the applicant does not meet these requirements, the application will be refused.

metadata.section_title: Requirements:

chunks.text:
### Requirements:

1.   (a) the applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability, and if applying for leave to remain, must not be an illegal entrant.
2.   (b) The applicant must be the child of a parent who has, or is at the same time being granted, valid entry clearance, leave to enter or remain, or indefinite leave to remain, as: 
    1.   (i) a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or
    2.   (ii) the partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker.

3.   or who has obtained British citizenship having previously held indefinite leave to remain as above.
4.   (c) The applicant must be under the age of 18 on the date the application is made, or if over 18 and applying for leave to remain, must have, or have last been granted, leave as the child of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker or as the child of the parent who had leave under another category of these Rules and who has since been granted, or, is at the same time being granted, leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker.
5.   (d) The applicant must not be married or in a civil partnership, must not have formed an independent family unit, and must not be leading an independent life and, if he is over the age of 16 on the date the application is made, he must provide the specified documents and information in paragraph 319H-SD to show that this requirement is met.
6.   (e) The applicant must not intend to stay in the UK beyond any period of leave granted to the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker parent.
7.   (f) Both of the applicant’s parents must either be lawfully present (other than as a visitor) in the UK, or being granted entry clearance or leave to remain (other than as a visitor) at the same time as the applicant or one parent must be lawfully present (other than as a visitor) in the UK and the other is being granted entry clearance or leave to remain (other than as a visitor) at the same time as the applicant, unless: 
    1.   (i) The Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker is the applicant’s sole surviving parent, or
    2.   (ii) The Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker parent has and has had sole responsibility for the applicant’s upbringing, or
    3.   (iii) there are serious or compelling family or other considerations which would make it desirable not to refuse the application and suitable arrangements have been made in the UK for the applicant’s care.

8.   (g) Unless the applicant is applying as the Child of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant who is a Tier 1 (Investor) Migrant, there must be a sufficient level of funds available to the applicant, as set out in Appendix E.
9.   (h) An applicant who is applying for leave to remain must not have last been granted: 
    1.   (i) entry clearance or leave as a: 
        1.   (a) visitor, including where they entered the United Kingdom from the Republic of Ireland to stay under the terms of articles 3A and 4 of the Immigration (Control of Entry through the Republic of Ireland) Order 1972 (as amended by the Immigration (Control of Entry through Republic of Ireland) (Amendment) Order 2014) on the basis of a visa issued by the Republic of Ireland authorities endorsed with the letters “BIVS” for the purpose of travelling and staying in the Republic for a period of 90 days or fewer; or
        2.   (b) short-term student (child)

    2.   (ii) temporary admission;
    3.   (iii) temporary release; or
    4.   (iv) after the date on which paragraph 1 of Schedule 10 to the Immigration Act 2016 is commenced, a grant of immigration bail in circumstances in which temporary admission or temporary release would previously have been granted.
    5.   (i) DELETED
    6.   (j) DELETED
    7.   (k) If the applicant is a child born in the UK to a Relevant Points Based System migrant or Appendix W Worker and their partner, the applicant must provide a full UK birth certificate showing the names of both parents.
    8.   (l) All arrangements for the child’s care and accommodation in the UK must comply with relevant UK legislation and regulations.
    9.   (m) The applicant must not be in the UK in breach of immigration laws except, where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, any current period of overstaying will be disregarded.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children applying to join or remain with a parent who has valid leave or British citizenship linked to a Points Based System or W Worker. Applicants must be under 18 (or meet specific age-related criteria), not married or in a civil partnership, and must not be leading an independent life or be an illegal entrant. Critical conditions include parental immigration status and age restrictions.

metadata.section_title: Specified documents and information

chunks.text:
### 319H-SD Specified documents and information

1.   Applicants who are over the age of 16 on the date the application is made must provide the following specified documents and information: 
    1.   (a) The applicant must provide two items from the list below confirming his residential address: 
        1.   (i) bank statements,
        2.   (ii) credit card bills,
        3.   (iii) driving licence,
        4.   (iv) NHS Registration document,
        5.   (v) letter from his current school, college or university, on official headed paper and bearing the official stamp of that organisation, and issued by an authorised official of that organisation.

    2.   (b) The documents submitted must be from two separate sources and dated no more than one calendar month before the date of the application.
    3.   (c) If the applicant pays rent or board, he must provide details of how much this amounts to each calendar month.
    4.   (d) If the applicant is residing separately from the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, he must provide: 
        1.   (i) reasons for residing away from the family home. Where this is due to academic endeavours he must provide confirmation from his university or college confirming his enrolment and attendance on the specific course, on official headed paper and bearing the official stamp of that organisation, and issued by an authorised official of that organisation,
        2.   (ii) the following evidence that he has been supported financially by his parents whilst residing away from the family home: 
            1.   (1) bank statements for the applicant covering the three months before the date of the application clearly showing the origin of the deposits; and
            2.   (2) bank statements for the applicant’s parent covering the three months before the date of the application also showing corroborating payments out of their account.
chunks.summary: Applicants over 16 must provide two recent, separate documents verifying their address, along with rent details if applicable. If living apart from a family member or migrant, they must submit explanations and official confirmation of academic enrollment. Conditions include document recency (within one month) and specific proof depending on their living situation.

metadata.section_title: 319I. Period and conditions of grant

chunks.text:
### 319I. Period and conditions of grant

1.   (a) Entry clearance and leave to remain will be granted for: 
    1.   (i) a period which expires on the same day as the leave granted to the parent whose leave expires first, or
    2.   (ii) Where both parents have, or are at the same time being granted, indefinite leave to remain, or have since become British citizens, leave to remain will be granted to the applicant for a period of 3 years.

2.   (b) Entry clearance and leave to remain under this route will be subject to the following conditions: 
    1.   (i) no recourse to public funds,
    2.   (ii) DELETED
    3.   (iii) DELETED
    4.   (iv) no employment as a professional sportsperson (including as a sports coach).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to family members seeking entry clearance or leave to remain. It stipulates that leave is granted for a period aligned with the parent’s status or for three years if parents are British citizens or have indefinite leave, and that applicants must not access public funds or work as professional sportspeople. Critical conditions include restrictions on employment and public funds during the grant period.
