metadata.section_title: 319J. Requirements for indefinite leave to remain

chunks.text:
### 319J. Requirements for indefinite leave to remain

To qualify for indefinite leave to remain under this route, an applicant must meet the requirements listed below. If the applicant meets these requirements, indefinite leave to remain will be granted. If the applicant does not meet these requirements, the application will be refused.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking indefinite leave to remain under the family route. They must satisfy specific eligibility criteria outlined in the rules; failure to do so results in application refusal. No exceptions or thresholds are specified beyond meeting the listed requirements.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules part 8: family members
Part: Immigration Rules part 8: family members
Section ID: 319J
Section: 319J. Requirements for indefinite leave to remain
Topic: leave-to-remain

Summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking indefinite leave to remain under the family route. They must satisfy specific eligibility criteria outlined in the rules; failure to do so results in application refusal. No exceptions or thresholds are specified beyond meeting the listed requirements.

### 319J. Requirements for indefinite leave to remain

To qualify for indefinite leave to remain under this route, an applicant must meet the requirements listed below. If the applicant meets these requirements, indefinite leave to remain will be granted. If the applicant does not meet these requirements, the application will be refused.

metadata.section_title: Requirements:

chunks.text:
### Requirements:

1.   (a) The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability and must not be an illegal entrant.
2.   (b) The applicant must be the child of a parent who has, or is at the same time being granted, indefinite leave to remain as: 
    1.   (i) a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or
    2.   (ii) the partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker.

3.   (c) The applicant must have, or have last been granted, leave as the child of or have been born in the United Kingdom to, the Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, or the partner of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker who is being granted indefinite leave to remain.
4.   (d) The applicant must not be married or in a civil partnership, must not have formed an independent family unit, and must not be leading an independent life, and if he is over the age of 16 on the date the application is made, he must provide the specified documents and information in paragraph 319H-SD to show that this requirement is met.
5.   (e) Both of an applicant’s parents must either be lawfully settled in the UK, or being granted indefinite leave to remain at the same time as the applicant, unless: 
    1.   (i) The Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker is the applicant’s sole surviving parent, or
    2.   (ii) The Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker parent has and has had sole responsibility for the applicant’s upbringing, or
    3.   (iii) there are serious and compelling family or other considerations which would make it desirable not to refuse the application and suitable arrangements have been made for the applicant’s care, or
    4.   (iv) One parent is, at the same time, being granted indefinite leave to remain as a Relevant Points Based System Migrant or Appendix W Worker, the other parent is lawfully present in the UK or being granted leave at the same time as the applicant, and the applicant was granted leave as the child of a Relevant Points Based System Migrant under the Rules in place before 9 July 2012.

6.   (f) The applicant has demonstrated sufficient knowledge of the English language and sufficient knowledge about life in the United Kingdom, in accordance with Appendix KoLL, unless he is under the age of 18 at the date on which the application is made.
7.   (g) If the applicant is a child born in the UK to a Relevant Points Based System migrant or Appendix W Worker and their partner, the applicant must provide a full UK birth certificate showing the names of both parents.
8.   (h) All arrangements for the child’s care and accommodation in the UK must comply with relevant UK legislation and regulations.
9.   (i) The applicant must not be in the UK in breach of immigration laws except, where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, any current period of overstaying will be disregarded.

Please note in the printed version of CM5829 these points appear in error numbered as an alternative version of 316D (iii) and (iv).

Critical conditions include age restrictions and proof of dependency.

chunks.text: ### Other family members of persons with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to family members of individuals with limited leave as refugees or humanitarian protection beneficiaries. They may apply for family reunion, subject to proof of relationship and health or security checks. Exceptions or thresholds are not specified in this extract.

metadata.section_title: Requirements for leave to enter the United Kingdom as the spouse or civil partner of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection.

chunks.text:
### Requirements for leave to enter the United Kingdom as the spouse or civil partner of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection.

1.   319L. The requirements to be met by a person seeking leave to enter the United Kingdom as the spouse or civil partner of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection, are that: 
    1.   (i) 
        1.   (a) the applicant is married to or the civil partner of a person who has limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection granted such status under the immigration rules and the parties are married or have formed a civil partnership after the person granted asylum or humanitarian protection left the country of his former habitual residence in order to seek asylum or humanitarian protection; and
        2.   (b) the applicant provides an original English language test certificate in speaking and listening from an English language test provider approved by the Secretary of State for these purposes, which clearly shows the applicant’s name and the qualification obtained (which must meet or exceed level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference) unless: 
            1.   (i) the applicant is aged 65 or over at the date he makes his application; or
            2.   (ii) the Secretary of State or Entry Clearance Officer considers that the applicant has a physical or mental condition that would prevent him from meeting the requirement; or
            3.   (iii) the Secretary of State or entry Clearance officer considers there are exceptional compassionate circumstances that would prevent the applicant from meeting the requirement; or
            4.   (iv) the applicant is a national of one of the following countries: Antigua and Barbuda; Australia; the Bahamas; Barbados; Belize; the British Overseas Territories; Canada; Dominica; Grenada; Guyana; Jamaica; New Zealand; St Kitts and Nevis; St Lucia; St Vincent and the Grenadines; Trinidad and Tobago; USA; Malta; or
            5.   (v) the applicant has obtained an academic qualification(not a professional or vocational qualification), which is deemed by Ecctis to meet the recognised standard of a Bachelor’s or Masters degree or PhD in the UK, from an educational establishment in one of the following countries: Antigua and Barbuda; Australia; The Bahamas; Barbados; Belize; the British Overseas Territories; Dominica; Grenada; Guyana; Ireland; Jamaica; New Zealand; St Kitts and Nevis; St Lucia; St Vincent and The Grenadines; Trinidad and Tobago; the UK; the USA; Malta; and provides the specified documents; or
            6.   (vi) the applicant has obtained an academic qualification (not a professional or vocational qualification) which is deemed by Ecctis to meet the recognised standard of a Bachelor’s or Masters degree or PhD in the UK, and 
                1.   (1) provides the specified evidence to show he has the qualification, and
                2.   (2) Ecctis has confirmed that the degree was taught or researched in English, or

            7.   (vii) has obtained an academic qualification (not a professional or vocational qualification) which is deemed by Ecctis to meet the recognised standard of a Bachelor’s or Masters degree or PhD in the UK, and provides the specified evidence to show: 
                1.   (1) he has the qualification, and
                2.   (2) that the qualification was taught or researched in English; and

    2.   (ii) the parties to the marriage or civil partnership have met; and
    3.   (iii) each of the parties intends to live permanently with the other as his or her spouse or civil partner and the marriage or civil partnership is subsisting; and
    4.   (iv) there will be adequate accommodation for the parties and any dependants without recourse to public funds in accommodation which they own or occupy exclusively; and
    5.   (v) the parties will be able to maintain themselves and any dependants adequately without recourse to public funds; and
    6.   (vi) the applicant holds a valid United Kingdom entry clearance for entry in this capacity.

1.   319M. Leave to enter the United Kingdom as the spouse or civil partner of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection may be granted for 63 months provided the Immigration Officer is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319l (i) - (vi) are met.

2.   319N. Leave to enter the United Kingdom as the spouse or civil partner of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection is to be refused if the Immigration Officer is not satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319L(i) - (vi) are met.
chunks.summary: Applicants must be spouses or civil partners of refugees or humanitarian protection beneficiaries, married or partnered after the latter left their home country to seek asylum. They must provide an approved English language test certificate (level A1), unless aged 65 or over.

metadata.section_title: Requirements for leave to enter the United Kingdom as the unmarried or same-sex partner of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection.

chunks.text:
### Requirements for leave to enter the United Kingdom as the unmarried or same-sex partner of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection.

1.   319O. The requirements to be met by a person seeking leave to enter the United Kingdom as the unmarried or same-sex partner of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection, are that: 
    1.   (i) 
        1.   (a) the applicant is the unmarried or same-sex partner of a person who has limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection granted such status under the immigration rules, and the parties have been living together in a relationship akin to either a marriage or civil partnership subsisting for two years or more after the person granted asylum or humanitarian protection left the country of his former habitual residence in order to seek asylum or humanitarian protection; and
        2.   (b) the applicant provides an English language test certificate in speaking and listening from an English language test provider approved by the Secretary of State for these purposes, which clearly shows the applicant’s name and the qualification obtained (which must meet or exceed level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference) unless: 
            1.   (i) the applicant is aged 65 or over at the time he makes his application;
            2.   (ii) the Secretary of State or entry Clearance officer considers that the applicant has a physical or mental condition that would prevent him from meeting the requirement;
            3.   (iii) the Secretary of State or Entry Clearance Officer considers there are exceptional compassionate circumstances that would prevent the applicant from meeting the requirement;
            4.   (iv) the applicant is a national of one of the following countries: Antigua and Barbuda; Australia; the Bahamas; Barbados; Belize; the British Overseas Territories, Canada; Dominica; Grenada; Guyana; Jamaica; New Zealand; St Kitts and Nevis; St Lucia; St Vincent and the Grenadines; Trinidad and Tobago; USA; Malta;
            5.   (v) the applicant has obtained an academic qualification(not a professional or vocational qualification), which is deemed by Ecctis to meet the recognised standard of a Bachelor’s or Masters degree or PhD in the UK, from an educational establishment in one of the following countries: Antigua and Barbuda; Australia; The Bahamas; Barbados; Belize; the British Overseas Territories, Dominica; Grenada; Guyana; Ireland; Jamaica; New Zealand; St Kitts and Nevis; St Lucia; St Vincent and The Grenadines; Trinidad and Tobago; the UK; the USA; Malta; and provides the specified documents; or
            6.   (vi) the applicant has obtained an academic qualification (not a professional or vocational qualification) which is deemed by Ecctis to meet the recognised standard of a Bachelor’s or Masters degree or PhD in the UK, and 
                1.   (1) provides the specified evidence to show he has the qualification, and
                2.   (2) Ecctis has confirmed that the degree was taught or researched in English, or

            7.   (vii) has obtained an academic qualification (not a professional or vocational qualification) which is deemed by Ecctis to meet the recognised standard of a Bachelor’s or Masters degree or PhD in the UK, and provides the specified evidence to show: 
                1.   (1) he has the qualification, and
                2.   (2) that the qualification was taught or researched in English; and

    2.   (ii) any previous marriage or civil partnership (or similar relationship) by either partner has permanently broken down; and
    3.   (iii) the parties are not involved in a consanguineous relationship with one another; and
    4.   (iv) there will be adequate accommodation for the parties and any dependants without recourse to public funds in accommodation which they own or occupy exclusively; and
    5.   (v) the parties will be able to maintain themselves and any dependants adequately without recourse to public funds; and
    6.   (vi) the parties intend to live together permanently; and
    7.   (vii) the applicant holds a valid United Kingdom entry clearance for entry in this capacity.

1.   319P. Leave to enter the United Kingdom as the unmarried or same-sex partner of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection may be granted for 63 months provided the Immigration Officer is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319O (i) - (vii) are met.
2.   319Q. Leave to enter the United Kingdom as the unmarried or same-sex partner of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitatrian protection is to be refused if the Immigration Officer is not satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319O (i) - (vii) are met.
chunks.summary: Applicants must demonstrate a two-year genuine relationship with a refugee or humanitarian protection beneficiary in the UK, and provide an approved English language test (A1 level), unless aged 65 or over.

metadata.section_title: Requirements for leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection

chunks.text:
### Requirements for leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection

1.   319R. The requirements to be met by a person seeking leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a parent or parents given limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection, are that the applicant: 
    1.   (i) is the child of a parent or parents granted limited leave to enter or remain as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection granted as such under the immigration rules; and
    2.   (ii) is under the age of 18, and
    3.   (iii) is not leading an independent life, is unmarried, is not in a civil partnership, and has not formed an independent family unit; and
    4.   (iv) was conceived after the person granted asylum or humanitarian protection left the country of his habitual residence in order to seek asylum in the UK; and
    5.   (v) can, and will, be accommodated adequately by the parent or parents the child is seeking to join without recourse to public funds in accommodation which the parent or parents the child is seeking to join, own or occupy exclusively; and
    6.   (vi) can, and will, be maintained adequately by the parent or parents the child is seeking to join, without recourse to public funds; and
    7.   (vii) if seeking leave to enter, holds a valid United Kingdom entry clearance for entry in this capacity.

1.   319S. limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection may be granted for 63 months provided the Immigration Officer is satisfied that each of the requirements in paragraph 319R (i)-(vii) are met.
2.   319T. Limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the child of a refugee or beneficiary humanitarian protection is to be refused if the Immigration Officer is not satisfied that each of the requirements in paragraph 319R (i) - (vii) are met.
chunks.summary: Applicants must be under 18, unmarried, and the child of a parent with refugee or humanitarian protection leave. They must have been conceived after the parent left their country seeking asylum and can be accommodated and maintained by that parent without public funds. Critical conditions include not leading an independent life and not in a civil partnership.

metadata.section_title: Requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the spouse or civil partner, unmarried or same - sex partner or child of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitatrian protection present and settled in the United Kingdom

chunks.text:
### Requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the spouse or civil partner, unmarried or same - sex partner or child of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitatrian protection present and settled in the United Kingdom

1.   319U. To qualify for indefinite leave to remain in the UK, an applicant must meet the requirements set out in paragraph 287 if the applicant is a spouse or civil partner, paragraph 295G if they are an unmarried or same-sex partner, or 298 if the applicant is a child and the sponsor must be present and settled in the United Kingdom at the time the application is made. if an applicant meets the requirements as set out in the relevant paragraphs, indefinite leave to remain will be granted. if the applicant does not meet these requirements, the application will be refused.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to spouses, civil partners, unmarried or same-sex partners, and children of refugees or beneficiaries of humanitarian protection in the UK. They must meet specific residence and relationship criteria outlined in various paragraphs, with the sponsor needing to be present and settled in the UK at application time; failure to do so results in refusal.

### Parents, grandparents and other dependent relatives of persons with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection

metadata.section_title: Requirements for leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection

chunks.text:
### Requirements for leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection

1.   319V. The requirements to be met by a person seeking leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection are that the person: 
    1.   (i) is related to a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom in one of the following ways: 
        1.   (a) parent or grandparent who is divorced, widowed, single or separated aged 65 years or over; or
        2.   (b) parents or grandparents travelling together of whom at least one is aged 65 or over; or
        3.   (c) a parent or grandparent aged 65 or over who has entered into a second relationship of marriage or civil partnership but cannot look to the spouse, civil partner or children of that second relationship for financial support; and where the person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom is able and willing to maintain the parent or grandparent and any spouse or civil partner or child of the second relationship who would be admissible as a dependant; or
        4.   (d) a parent or grandparent under the age of 65 if living alone outside the United Kingdom in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; or
        5.   (e) parents or grandparents travelling together who are both under the age of 65 if living in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; or
        6.   (f) the son, daughter, sister, brother, uncle or aunt over the age of 18 if living alone outside the United Kingdom in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; and

    2.   (ii) is joining a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom; and
    3.   (iii) is financially wholly or mainly dependent on the relative who has limited leave to enter or remain as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection in the United Kingdom; and
    4.   (iv) can, and will, be accommodated adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds, in accommodation which the sponsor owns or occupies exclusively; and
    5.   (v) can, and will, be maintained adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds; and
    6.   (vi) has no other close relatives in his own country to whom he could turn for financial support; and
    7.   (vii) if seeking leave to enter, holds a valid United Kingdom entry clearance for entry in this capacity, or, if seeking leave to remain, holds valid leave to remain in another capacity.

1.   319VA. Limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom may be granted for 5 years provided on arrival, a valid passport or other identity document is produced to the Immigration Officer and the applicant has entry clearance for entry in this capacity. Limited leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom may be granted provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319V (i)-(vii) is met.
2.   319VB.Limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom is to be refused if, on arrival, a valid passport or other identity document is not produced to the Immigration Officer and the applicant does not have entry clearance for entry in this capacity. Limited leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom is to be refused if the Secretary of State is not satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319V (i)-(vii) is met.

They must demonstrate specific familial relationships, age criteria, and the ability of the refugee or beneficiary to financially support them, with certain conditions for those under or over 65 and in second relationships.

Summary: The rules apply to dependent relatives—parents, grandparents, or others—seeking UK leave to join a refugee or humanitarian protection claimant. They must demonstrate specific familial relationships, age criteria, and the ability of the refugee or beneficiary to financially support them, with certain conditions for those under or over 65 and in second relationships.

### Requirements for leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection

1.   319V. The requirements to be met by a person seeking leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection are that the person: 
    1.   (i) is related to a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom in one of the following ways: 
        1.   (a) parent or grandparent who is divorced, widowed, single or separated aged 65 years or over; or
        2.   (b) parents or grandparents travelling together of whom at least one is aged 65 or over; or
        3.   (c) a parent or grandparent aged 65 or over who has entered into a second relationship of marriage or civil partnership but cannot look to the spouse, civil partner or children of that second relationship for financial support; and where the person with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom is able and willing to maintain the parent or grandparent and any spouse or civil partner or child of the second relationship who would be admissible as a dependant; or
        4.   (d) a parent or grandparent under the age of 65 if living alone outside the United Kingdom in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; or
        5.   (e) parents or grandparents travelling together who are both under the age of 65 if living in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; or
        6.   (f) the son, daughter, sister, brother, uncle or aunt over the age of 18 if living alone outside the United Kingdom in the most exceptional compassionate circumstances; and

    2.   (ii) is joining a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom; and
    3.   (iii) is financially wholly or mainly dependent on the relative who has limited leave to enter or remain as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection in the United Kingdom; and
    4.   (iv) can, and will, be accommodated adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds, in accommodation which the sponsor owns or occupies exclusively; and
    5.   (v) can, and will, be maintained adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds; and
    6.   (vi) has no other close relatives in his own country to whom he could turn for financial support; and
    7.   (vii) if seeking leave to enter, holds a valid United Kingdom entry clearance for entry in this capacity, or, if seeking leave to remain, holds valid leave to remain in another capacity.

1.   319VA. Limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom may be granted for 5 years provided on arrival, a valid passport or other identity document is produced to the Immigration Officer and the applicant has entry clearance for entry in this capacity. Limited leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom may be granted provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319V (i)-(vii) is met.
2.   319VB.Limited leave to enter the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom is to be refused if, on arrival, a valid passport or other identity document is not produced to the Immigration Officer and the applicant does not have entry clearance for entry in this capacity. Limited leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom is to be refused if the Secretary of State is not satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319V (i)-(vii) is met.

metadata.section_title: Requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection who is present and settled in the United Kingdom or of a former refugee or beneficiary humanitarian protection, who is now a British Citizen.

chunks.text:
### Requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection who is present and settled in the United Kingdom or of a former refugee or beneficiary humanitarian protection, who is now a British Citizen.

1.   319W. The requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection who is now present and settled in the United Kingdom or who is now a British Citizen are that: 
    1.   (i) the applicant has limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom in accordance with paragraph 319V as a dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom; and
    2.   (ii) the sponsor the applicant was admitted to join is now present and settled in the United Kingdom, or is now a British Citizen; and
    3.   (iii) the applicant is financially wholly or mainly dependent on the relative who is present and settled in the United Kingdom; and
    4.   (iv) the applicant can, and will, be accommodated adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds, in accommodation which the sponsor owns or occupies exclusively; and
    5.   (v) the applicant can, and will, be maintained adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds; and
    6.   (vi) the applicant has no other close relatives in their country of former habitual residence to whom he could turn for financial support; and
    7.   (vii) does not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   319WA. Indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection who is present and settled in the United Kingdom, or who is now a British Citizen may be granted provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319W (i)-(vii) is met.

2.   319WB. Indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person present and settled in the United Kingdom is to be refused if the Secretary of State is not satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319W (i)-(vii) is met.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependents of refugees or beneficiaries of humanitarian protection now settled or British citizens. They must have had limited leave, be financially dependent, and accommodated and maintained without recourse to public funds, with the sponsor present and settled in the UK. Critical conditions include dependency status, settlement, and adequate support.

1.   319W. The requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection who is now present and settled in the United Kingdom or who is now a British Citizen are that: 
    1.   (i) the applicant has limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom in accordance with paragraph 319V as a dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection with limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom; and
    2.   (ii) the sponsor the applicant was admitted to join is now present and settled in the United Kingdom, or is now a British Citizen; and
    3.   (iii) the applicant is financially wholly or mainly dependent on the relative who is present and settled in the United Kingdom; and
    4.   (iv) the applicant can, and will, be accommodated adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds, in accommodation which the sponsor owns or occupies exclusively; and
    5.   (v) the applicant can, and will, be maintained adequately, together with any dependants, without recourse to public funds; and
    6.   (vi) the applicant has no other close relatives in their country of former habitual residence to whom he could turn for financial support; and
    7.   (vii) does not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   319WA. Indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection who is present and settled in the United Kingdom, or who is now a British Citizen may be granted provided the Secretary of State is satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319W (i)-(vii) is met.

2.   319WB. Indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as the parent, grandparent or other dependent relative of a person present and settled in the United Kingdom is to be refused if the Secretary of State is not satisfied that each of the requirements of paragraph 319W (i)-(vii) is met.
